item.title: WordPress
item.description:
Lecture slides from this week

This week we'll be covering WordPress, the worlds most widely used open source CMS. WordPress is great for simple websites of which the web is made up of many. It's why it powers (estimates, numbers differ by source) 33% to as much as 50% of sites on the internet.

These sites could be everything from the Whitehouse down to every individual blog / new acount on wordpress.com (SaaS solution version) which is why people take some of that number with a grain of salt.

It's a great platform to start your own website on but it's run into some recent controversies which are worth exploring - namely the battle for the heart of the community around a text editor. It's weird to think about, but when a CMS lives and dies by the ease of content entry, you can understand why the new core mandatory text editor called Gutenberg ¬†would attract positive and negative attention.

With plans to phase out the "Classic Editor" in 2020 many people in the community are at a cross-roads: Continue to trust the same core community that "took away" their beloved simple HTML editor, or forge a new path. We'll look briefly at the concept of community forks through the context of ClassicPress, a popular WordPress alternative that's gaining traction as the more community centric CMS.

With parallels to Drupal and it's popular fork Backdrop (topic for next lab) we'll see that it's not always code that leads to inflection points in groups but the process by which that code is formed, agreed upon, and ultimately pushed into the main project everyone's aligned with.

WordPress is a great resume builder both in terms of the platform as well as putting on your resume that you have experience with it, so let's dig in and check it out in ReclaimHosting ¬†once more!

item.title: GravCMS
item.description:
Slides about CPanel & GravCMS from class

This week kicks off Reclaim hosting and our Content Management System section of the course. We're going to be covering four different content management systems in this section of the course leveraging Reclaim hosting to skip a lot of the tediousness of setting up and playing with a CMS.

We'll talk about CPanel in the high level as far as what function it provides and navigate some of the parts of it a bit, though it won't be the focus. CPanel has been around forever (in web terms) and is still a powerful way to abstract away the complexity of managing servers and get you access to installing apps via a nice UI and mild technical knowledge.

Listing CMS "Site building" skills on a resume is a sure fire way to get noticed by certain companies looking for people who can hit the ground running with their internal systems. It demonstrates that you know how to navigate technical systems and can be taught out to administer them (potentially).

It's also a bit crazy as CMSs really are just big storage houses of information with text editors and other UIs that help streamline getting large groups of media and content on the web. The crazy part is, this really isn't that hard to do (as we'll demonstrate through these units) but a lot of people are so afraid of them that they won't touch them.

Master any one of these popular CMSs coming up (especially Drupal coming up) and you'll stand out in any organization that manages web projects or interfaces regularly with the web properties of the company directly.

item.title: After class reflection
item.description:
All assignments are setup as labs and you'll be starting into them at the end of class. Once finished with the lab, you'll demonstrate you've done the work by reflecting on it in the form of a written response as well as a video response. Then we'll review some of the responses at the start of the next class.¬†Scroll down to read both things that you are expected to complete each week as part of reflection on the topic of the lab. Yes I enjoy bold text.

Written response

To each technology, I'd like you to write a short blog post that reads like a one-page white paper about the technology at hand. Try to keep it to around 500 words but thoroughness is more important then "did I make the paper long enough".

As long as it answers questions like the following:

  • What is it and why does it exist
  • What industries use it / who are players that popularize it?
  • What alternatives exist to it?
  • Links / Resources for people who want to learn more about it
  • What you struggled with in using it?
  • What you liked most about using it?

Video response

Explainer videos are great, especially for people on the go via podcasts or who are looking to get a refresher on a topic before a meeting. Make a 3-5 minute screencast that sets up what the topic is, and runs through some brief examples of it. This is open to interpretation but you are trying to explain to others why this topic is valuable and when they'd use it.

  • Say quickly who you are
  • Explain in 30 seconds what the topic is, who's using it or why it's useful
  • Talk about the topic while showing a demo of it or place you found most useful to learn
  • Show links to resources where you can learn more about it
  • Awesome sign off phrase to remember you by

Here are a few examples of the kind of formality that is expected (flip on screencast software, record screen, talk). This will be explained more as we go into the course but it's effectively a double lab as far as points and time involved. There is no final exam so it's just a final project

item.title: Building your digital identity
item.description:
Slides from the talk in class

No one knows who you are if you're not effectively communicating. I recall a colleague several years ago getting pissed that I was invited to speak some place. "It's like no one knows I exist or appreciates what I know". He was absolutely just as or more tallented than I was... what was the difference?

  • I've blogged openly about tech and life since 2008
  • I've got hundreds of YouTube videos ranging from "Hey look at this thing" to "let's learn about..." to "We're going to burn down this space"
  • I've got unified social media accounts that signal boost content from the other spaces

As a result of having a unified social media front and regular presence on blogs / YouTube, I've gotten to speak nationally on a regular basis the last ten years. Every recorded association of a brand or event to you personally is another form of signal boosting.

Theory

A theory I learned about in Grad school that stuck with me the most is called Actor Network Theory (ANT). ANT can be argued as to if it's actually a theory, but the TLDR; is that all things influence each other.

For information sciences though, it's saying that anything created influences anything else created. This is particularly potent in the digital space when we can create a logo, brand, business, website, identity, or platform seemingly out of thin air. If I post on YouTube, I'm not just broadcasting there and increasing my brand recognition in that space. It's aggregated to blogs, it shows up in Google and Bing search results. Its lifted for replication on Russian botnet sites.

All of this, amplifies your voice and reach far beyond you speaking in public (again, duh). But if you recognize this, you can also weaponize it to your advantage (or be a Russian troll bot online and corrupt other countries cultures, I mean tomatoe tomatto). Through intentionality, we can increase our profile as technology professionals and begin to build a portfolio that anyone can stumble on (or seek out intentionally) to increase their knowledge.

item.title: Questions driven teaching
item.description:
In all the technologies and skillsets we'll explore in this course, I want you to approach them with the same questions that I have explored in my career. These simple questions will help you decipher what's going to get you the furthest for the longest.

Technological sustainability is not easy; both in remaining relevant by sustaining your own skills as well as the sustained use of any solution by anyone or their organization.

What problem does this solve?

Who built this?

Where is this being used?

How can I go about using it?

Why do people use this over alternatives? (and what are the top 3 alternatives)

With each problem / solution space we look at in this course we're going to look at it through the lens of these questions.
